children.name: praise
children.definition: /preɪz/  to say that you admire someone or approve of something good that they have done:
examples: tán dương ca ngợi
▪ Fire chiefs praised a 10-year-old girl who saved her brother’s life yesterday.
praise somebody for something
tán dương ca ngợi ai đó vì việc gì đó
▪ Local people were praised for their calm response to the crisis.
highly praised
được tán dương ca ngợi
▪ His column was a regular and highly praised feature of the newspaper.

children.name: congratulate
children.definition: /kənˈgrætʃɑleɪt/  to tell someone that you are pleased or impressed because they have achieved something special:
examples: chúc mừng
▪ I would like to congratulate all the prizewinners.
congratulate somebody on (doing) something
chúc mừngai đó vì việc gì đó
▪ The President congratulated him on winning the title.
▪ I wrote a letter congratulating him on his appointment.
congratulate somebody for (doing) something
chúc mừngai đó vì việc gì đó
▪ The committee is to be congratulated for presenting its findings in such an informative manner.

children.name: compliment
children.definition: /ˈkɒmplɪment, ˈkɒmpləmentǁˈkɑːm-/  to tell someone that you like the way they look or that you are pleased with something that they have done:
examples: khen ngợi, ca ngợi
▪ She blushed when men complimented her.
compliment somebody on something
khen ngợi, ca ngợiai đó vì việc gì đó
▪ Everyone complimented me on my new hairstyle.

children.name: be complimentary about
children.definition: /biː ˌkɒmplˈmentəri əbaʊtǁ-ˌkɑːm-/  to say good or approving things about a person or their achievements:ca ngợi về
examples: ▪ Peter is always very complimentary about your work.
▪ She was actually highly complimentary about you.

children.name: say good things about
children.definition: /ˌseɪ gʊd ˈθɪŋz əbaʊt/  if you say good things about someone, you praise their abilities, usually in their work:nói tốt về
examples: ▪ People are saying really good things about you -- that you are well-trained, are thorough, conscientious...

children.name: speak highly of
children.definition: /ˌspiːk ˈhaɪli ɒv/  to praise someone or their work because you admire them:ca ngợi
examples: ▪ I’m so pleased to meet you -- my wife has always spoken very highly of you.
▪ All her former clients speak highly of her legal skills.

children.name: pay tribute to
children.definition: /ˌpeɪ ˈtrɪbjuːt tuː/  to praise someone publicly, especially to show respect for them and what they have achieved:ngợi ca, khen ngợi
examples: ▪ John Motum, presenting the trophy, paid tribute to the players and coaches.
▪ Friends of the actor paid tribute to his talent and expressed shock as news of his death became public.

children.name: put in a good word for
children.definition: /ˌpʊt ɪn ə ˌgʊd ˈwɜːʳd fɔːʳ/  if someoneputs in a good word foryou with someone in a position of authority, they praise you to them, especially in order to help you to get a job or to avoid punishment:nói tốt cho
examples: ▪ The producers told me later that I got the job because Paul put in a good word for me.
put in a good word for somebody with somebody
nói tốt về ai đó với ai đó
▪ Can you put in a good word for me with your colleagues on the council?

children.name: sing the praises of sb/sth
children.definition: to praise someone or something:The newspapers have been singing the praises of Italy's new star player.

children.name: what you say when you praise sb
well done
children.definition: British /good jobAmerican /ˌwel ˈdʌn, ˌgʊd ˈdʒɒbǁ-ˈdʒɑːb/ spoken say this to someone when they have done something well or succeeded in doing something difficult:làm tốt lắm
examples: ▪ Well done! You got all the answers right.
▪ Good job, John! That was a great shot.

children.name: congratulations
children.definition: /kənˌgrætʃɑˈleɪʃənz/sayorwritethis to someone when they have done something good or special:chúc mừng
examples: ▪ Congratulations! Is it a girl or boy?
congratulations on
chúc mừng cho
▪ Congratulations on your new job, Jenny.
congratulations on doing something
chúc mừng cho việc gì đó
▪ Congratulations on passing your driving test.

children.name: way to go
children.definition: /ˌweɪ tə ˈgəʊ/ Americanspokeninformal use this to praise someone who has just done something very good or impressive:
examples: chúc mừng, làm tốt đấy
▪ ‘I got accepted at Stanford.’ ‘Way to go!’
▪ Way to go Sam! Nice hit!

children.name: praise that is given to sb or st
praise
children.definition: /preɪz/  things you say to someone to show that youadmirethem orapproveof what they have done:
examples: lời tán dương ca ngợi
praise for
lời tán dương ca ngợi cho
▪ The police deserve a lot of praise for the way they handled the situation.
win/earn praisebe praised for something
được nhiều lời tán dương ca ngợi
▪ The charity has earned widespread praise for its work.
high praisepraise from someone important or respected :
khen ngợi nồng nhiệt
▪ She said you have talent, and that’s high praise coming from a best-selling author like her.

children.name: compliment
children.definition: /ˈkɒmplɪmənt, ˈkɒmpləməntǁˈkɑːm-/  what you say when you tell someone they look nice or they have done something well:
examples: lời khen ngợi
▪ ‘You have lovely hair,’ said Bob to Emma, who blushed at the compliment.
pay/give somebody a compliment
khen ngợi ai đó
▪ He’s always paying her compliments and buying her flowers.
shower somebody with complimentsgive someone a lot of compliments
khen ngợi ai đó nhiệt thành
▪ Rob always showered me with compliments and made me feel special.

children.name: flattery
children.definition: /ˈflætəri/  nice things that you say about someone, which may not be true, in order to get something that you want from them:
examples: lời tâng bốc xu nịnh
▪ She used a mixture of persuasion and flattery to get what she wanted.
flattery will get you nowhereuse this to tell someone that flattery will not help them get what they want :có nịnh cũng vô ích thôi
▪ I’ll choose the best person for the job, so flattery will get you nowhere.

children.name: recognition
children.definition: /ˌrekəgˈnɪʃən/  if someone getsrecognitionfor their work, they get praised publicly, often after a long time:sự công nhận
examples: ▪ She had to spend 10 years as a struggling artist, before receiving any recognition for her work.
▪ Although he was popular in Europe, Hendrix had yet to achieve recognition in his home country.

children.name: commendation
children.definition: /ˌkɒmənˈdeɪʃənǁˌkɑː-/  formal an official statement praising someone, especially someone who has been very brave or very successful:sự tuyên dương
examples: ▪ Patroni received an official commendation after rescuing twelve people from a sinking ship.
▪ After winning the world championship, he received a note of commendation from the President.

children.name: to praise sb in an insincere way
flatter
children.definition: /ˈflætəʳ/  to say nice things that you donot meanabout someone, especially in order to get something from them:
examples: tâng bốc xu nịnh, bợ đỡ
▪ Flatter her a little - tell her she’s beautiful.
▪ His flattering comments embarrassed her.

children.name: butter up
children.definition: /ˌbʌtər ˈʌp/  informal to say nice things to someone in order to make them do something you want:nịnh
examples: butter somebody up
nịnh ai đó
▪ It’s no use trying to butter me up -- I’m not changing my mind.
butter up somebody
nịnh ai đó
▪ The bank has to butter up investors in this fiercely competitive market.

children.name: to praise sb or st a lot
be full of praise for
children.definition: /biː ˌfʊl əv ˈpreɪz fɔːʳ/ hết lời ca ngợi
examples: ▪ The press were full of praise for the whole production.
▪ Ramsey, who hosts a Christian radio show, is full of praise for the two new congressmen.

children.name: sing somebody’s praises
children.definition: /ˌsɪŋ somebodyˈs ˈpreɪzz/  to praise someone very highly and very frequently:khen tặng
examples: ▪ Craig adored Jane and would sing her praises to anyone who would listen.
▪ Feminists have long sung the praises of writers such as Germaine Greer and Simone de Beauvoir.

children.name: rave about
children.definition: /ˈreɪv əbaʊt/  informal to talk or write about something, saying how wonderful you think it is:khen ngợi về
examples: ▪ Critics are raving about the new show.
▪ I bought some of that Colombian coffee you used to rave about.

children.name: glorify
children.definition: /ˈglɔːrɪfaɪ, ˈglɔːrəfaɪ/  to praise someone and their achievements very highly, in order to make them seem more important than they really are:ngợi khen
examples: ▪ The emperor’s achievements were glorified in numerous poems.
▪ The book is a vain attempt to glorify the name of one of the worst dictators in modern history.

children.name: heap/lavish praise on
children.definition: /ˌhiːp, ˌlævɪʃ ˈpreɪz ɒn/  to say things that show you admire someone or approve of what they have done:ca ngợi, tán dương
examples: ▪ It’s nice to receive a letter heaping praise on someone for a job well done, for a change.
▪ She is modest and generous, lavishing praise on the musicians she has worked with.

children.name: to be praised in newspapers or by many people
get a good press
children.definition: /get ə ˌgʊd ˈpres/  if somethinggets a good press, it is praised in the newspapers, on television etc:nhận nhiều lời khen ngợi
examples: ▪ I haven’t read it yet, but I know her latest novel got a very good press.
▪ Eastern European cars have never really had a good press in this country.

children.name: get rave reviews
children.definition: /get ˌreɪv rɪˈvjuːz/  informal if something such as a new book, film, or playgets rave reviews,it is praised a lot in newspapers and magazines:nhận được phản hồi tích cực
examples: ▪ Her roles in ‘Miami Vice’ and ‘A Room with a View’ got rave reviews.
▪ Despite getting rave reviews, the film was not a box office hit.

children.name: acclaimed
children.definition: /əˈkleɪmd/  if something such as a film, performance, or achievementis acclaimed, it is praised publicly by people who have a lot of knowledge about that subject:được tung hô
examples: highly acclaimed
được tung hô nhiệt liệt
▪ Paul Simon’s solo career has resulted in a string of highly acclaimed albums.
widely acclaimed
được tung hô rộng rãi
▪ Her work on finding a cure for cancer has been widely acclaimed by her colleagues in the medical profession.
critically acclaimedpraised by critics
được giới phê bình đánh giá cao
▪ ‘The West Wing’ is one of the most critically acclaimed TV series in the USA.

children.name: much-praised
children.definition: /ˌmʌtʃ ˈpreɪzd◂/  praised a lot by many people:nhiều người ca tụng
examples: ▪ They run a much-praised restaurant in Soho.
▪ The Beatles’ album ‘Sergeant Pepper’ was much praised when it first came out.

children.name: be hailed as
children.definition: /biː ˈheɪld æz/  if something or someone newis hailed assomething, they are praised a lot and are called something very good:được tung hô như
examples: ▪ She is being hailed as the new Marilyn Monroe.
▪ The new peace agreement is being hailed as a major breakthrough.
▪ When it was first introduced, the birth control pill was hailed as a wonder drug.

children.name: words for describing statements that praise sb or st
glowing
children.definition: /ˈgləʊɪŋ/  full of praise:đầy tự hào
examples: ▪ Despite glowing reviews about the company’s core businesses, its shares have fallen.
▪ The young soldiers who returned home gave glowing accounts of Paul’s bravery and devotion to duty.
in glowing terms
một cách đầy tự hào
with words of high praise
▪ Stephen always talks in glowing terms of your work.
glowingly[adverb]
đầy tự hào
▪ The reviewers spoke glowingly about a young actor named Jack Nicholson.

children.name: complimentary
children.definition: /ˌkɒmplɪˈmentəri◂, ˌkɒmpləˈmentəri◂ǁˌkɑːm-/ complimentaryremarks say good and approving things about someone or their achievements:ca ngợi, tán tụng
examples: highly complimentary
đầy ca ngợi, tán tụng
▪ Everything I’ve heard about your work has been highly complimentary.

children.name: favourable
children.definition: British /favorableAmerican /ˈfeɪvərəbəl/ favourablereports, remarks etc say good things about the person, film, event etc that they are about:đầy hứa hẹn
examples: ▪ Responses to his latest movie have generally been favourable.
▪ I don’t want to hear your opinion -- unless it’s favourable of course.
